ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: Postictal
Notes: 1=No; 2=Yes

ElementDescription: Postictal - Please describe (including duration since last seizure)
Unwell
Notes: 1=No; 2=Yes

ElementDescription: Unwell - Please describe
Current medications (list of med name(s) only; no dosage)
Please note travel over the past 24 hours
Current state - Other comments
Follows in well-lit room, 10cm from examiner's face, without voice prompt
Notes: 0=Fixes and follows examiner's face consistently; 25=Fixes, occasionally/inconsistently follows examiner face; 50=Fixes only, does not follow; 75=Blinks to bright light (otoscope on maximum power); 100=Does not fix, follow or blink to light

ElementDescription: Use the standard OKNDrumï¿½app on iPad (minimum 10 inch screen size) at full intensity in darkened room held 5-10 cm from the child's eyes for 30 seconds. Both directions tested
Notes: 0=Normal OKN; 33.333=Ignored OKN - notice then look away; 66.666=Inconsistent OKN, Reduced OKN (movements present but reduced in amplitude, or loss of one visual field; 100=No visual field, absent OKN

ElementDescription: Head control in sitting - support trunk in an upright position if required
Notes: 0=Full, active range of motion to look left or right; 33.333=Limited range of motion to look left or right, lack of chin control; 66.666=Can get head into alignment whether momentary or longer; 100=No head control

ElementDescription: Supine lying to sitting
Notes: 0=Moves from laying to sitting independently - good head and trunk control; 20=Moves into sitting with some limitations - lag in head control, or uses own arm to assist; 40=Minimal assistance to guide getting into sitting - a light touch, one hand held; 60=Pull child into sitting, child holds head in line with body through a portion or all of the movement; 80=Pull child into sitting, may momentarily tighten muscles through the neck but does not align head with body; 100=No, minimal effort, full assist

ElementDescription: Sit 20 seconds sitting on a chair (7 months or older only)
Notes: 0=Able to sit for 20 seconds independently, fully safe, can step away from the child; 20=Able to sit for 20 seconds under supervision (spotting, stand by assist) or may require use of one or both upper extremities to prop for maintaining sitting; 40=Sits for 20 seconds with minimal assistance - a light touch, one hand held; 60=Sits for 20 seconds with moderate assistance - two hands held, trunk support; 80=Sits less than 20 seconds with moderate assistance; 100=Maximal assistance, unable to maintain sitting

ElementDescription: Sit to stand extent of testing based on parent report of known motor skills, e.g., if unable to get up from floor, start with getting up from chair (15 months or older only)
Notes: 0=Moves from sitting on the floor to stand independently, without using hands and stabilizing independently; 20=Moves from sitting on the floor to stand but uses own hand(s) for support on self or furniture; 40=Cannot stand from floor, but stands from chair on own (may use own hands to get out of chair but independently); 60=Stands from chair with minimal assist (one hand, one hand from assistant, light touch); 80=Stands from chair with moderate assist (two hands, trunk support); 100=Maximal assist, unable to stand from chair

ElementDescription: Stand 20 seconds (15 months or older only)
Notes: 0=Stands independently for 20 seconds, without limitations, can step away from the child; 20=Stands independently for 20 seconds, with limitations - with supervision (spotting, stand by assist), wide base, bracing; 40=Stands for 20 seconds with minimal assistance - one hand held, light touch; 60=Stands for 20 seconds with moderate assistance - two hands held, trunk support; 80=Stands for less than 20 seconds with moderate assistance; 100=Maximal assistance, unable to maintain standing position

ElementDescription: Walk 10 steps (18 months or older only)
Notes: 0=Walks without limitations, can step away from the child without fear of their falling; 20=Walks with limitations - e.g., wide base, bracing, apraxia, stand by assist; 40=Walks 10 steps with minimal assistance - light touch, one hand held; 60=Walks 10 steps with moderate assistance - two hands held, trunk support; 80=Walks less than 10 steps with moderate assistance; 100=Maximal assistance, unable to walk

ElementDescription: Hand function - Evaluate using the child's own objects
Notes: 0=Able to freely manipulate objects including small objects e.g. transferring objects from hand to hand (fully formed, upper limb is free of support); 20=Consistently uses thumb when grasping small objects e.g. small pieces of food; 40=Rake grasp - Uses only fingers or inconsistent thumb when grasping small objects e.g. small pieces of food; consistent function (feeds self, plays, etc.); 60=Active grasp and hold large object, - e.g. toy for the size of the child's hand, child's own spoon or cup; 80=Holds object only if placed in hands for at least 2 seconds - e.g. small toy, small ball, spoon, cup (may throw the object within 2 seconds); 100=No hand use

ElementDescription: Reaching
Notes: 0=Reaches for small objects accurately (i.e. hits the target smoothly); 25=Reaches for small objects with difficulty (dysmetria, poor targeting, needs assistance (weakness)); 50=Reaches for large objects or people; 75=Bats at or pushes away objects or people or eye/face rubbing- intentional; 100=No intentional reaching

ElementDescription: Speech (verbal) (18 months or older only)
Notes: 0=Sentences or Phrases - 2 or more words - vocal, normal for age; 20=Sentences or Phrases - 2 or more words - vocal, but not normal for age; 40=Single words - vocal - e.g. yes or no; 60=Purposeful vocalization or word approximation; 80=Non-purposeful vocalization; 100=No vocalization

ElementDescription: Speech (verbal) (15-17 months only)
Notes: 0=Single words - vocal - e.g. yes or no; 33.333=Purposeful vocalization or word approximation; 66.666=Non purposeful vocalization; 100=No vocalization

ElementDescription: Speech (verbal) (less than 15 months only)
Notes: 0=Purposeful vocalization; 50=Non purposeful vocalization; 100=No vocalization

ElementDescription: Language (non-verbal) (18 months or more only)
Notes: 0=Verbal communication is accompanied by facial expression, gestures (body language) and eye contact in a social setting, normal; 25=Sentences or Phrases - 2 or more words -signed or device, multiple choices/proficient with a device, reduced social orientation; 50=Consistent single words in signs or device or gestures e.g. uses head for yes or no, pointing (finger or hand), blinking, switch, or eye gaze, single choices with a device; 75=Inconsistent or rare use (1 or 2 occasions throughout interaction) of single words in signs or device or gestures e.g. uses head for yes or no, pointing (finger or hand), blinking, switch, or eye gaze, single choices with a device; 100=No gestures for communication

ElementDescription: Language (non-verbal) (less than 18 months only)
Notes: 0=Consistent single words in signs or device or gestures e.g. uses head for yes or no, pointing (finger or hand), blinking, switch, or eye gaze, single choices with a device; 50=Inconsistent or rare use (1 or 2 occasions throughout interaction) of single words in signs or device or gestures e.g. uses head for yes or no, pointing (finger or hand), blinking, switch, or eye gaze, single choices with a device; 100=No gestures for communication

ElementDescription: Receptive Language (tested by clinician) (18 months or older only)
Notes: 0=Follows 2 step commands, e.g. close your eyes and stick out your tongue, take the ball and give it; 25=Follows 1 step commands, e.g. hand me the toy, touch your nose, close your eyes; 50=Responds to language (i.e. name and other) with eye contact or similar (smile, alerts, quiets, calms) for at least 10 seconds (out of 30 seconds of direct conversation); 75=Responds to voice or language- response short lived and fleeting; 100=Does not respond

ElementDescription: Receptive Language (tested by clinician) (less than 18 months only)
Notes: 0=Responds to language (i.e. name and other) with eye contact or similar (smile, alerts, quiets, calms) for at least 10 seconds (out of 30 seconds of direct conversation); 50=Responds to voice or language- response short lived and fleeting; 100=Does not respond

ElementDescription: Alertness and attention is observed in the child's activities in relation to interactions and engagement with the environment
Notes: 0=Alert/attentive and engaged in sensory activities with a person (e.g. watching, listening, smiling) consistently when offered, normal; 25=Alert/attentive and engaged in sensory activities with an object (e.g. watching video on iPad, listening); 50=Awake but attention has to be drawn by examiner or surroundings for most of the exam; 75=Awake but not attentive/interactive to the examiner or surroundings for most of the exam; 100=Drowsy or asleep for most of the exam

ElementDescription: Eye Alignment
Notes: 0=Normal; 50=Disconjugate, intermittent; 100=Disconjugate, constant

ElementDescription: Roving
Notes: 0=Not present; 50=Intermittent; 100=Persistent

ElementDescription: Nystagmus
Notes: 0=Not present; 50=Intermittent; 100=Persistent

ElementDescription: Nystagmus, specify type - Horizontal
Notes: 0=Unselected; 1=Selected

ElementDescription: Nystagmus, specify type - Vertical
Notes: 0=Unselected; 1=Selected

ElementDescription: Nystagmus, specify type - Rotatory
Notes: 0=Unselected; 1=Selected

ElementDescription: Muscle tone - Axial
Notes: -100=Severe hypotonia; -50=Mild hypotonia; 0=Normal tone; 50=Mild stiffness; 100=Severe stiffness

ElementDescription: Muscle tone - Upper limb scored
Notes: 1=Right; 2=Left

ElementDescription: Muscle tone - Shoulder
Notes: -100=Severe hypotonia; -50=Mild hypotonia; 0=Normal tone; 50=Mild stiffness; 100=Severe stiffness

ElementDescription: Muscle tone - Elbow
Notes: -100=Severe hypotonia; -50=Mild hypotonia; 0=Normal tone; 50=Mild stiffness; 100=Severe stiffness

ElementDescription: Muscle tone - Wrist
Notes: -100=Severe hypotonia; -50=Mild hypotonia; 0=Normal tone; 50=Mild stiffness; 100=Severe stiffness

ElementDescription: Muscle tone - Lower limb scored
Notes: 1=Right; 2=Left

ElementDescription: Muscle tone - Hip
Notes: -100=Severe hypotonia; -50=Mild hypotonia; 0=Normal tone; 50=Mild stiffness; 100=Severe stiffness

ElementDescription: Muscle tone - Knee
Notes: -100=Severe hypotonia; -50=Mild hypotonia; 0=Normal tone; 50=Mild stiffness; 100=Severe stiffness

ElementDescription: Muscle tone - Ankle
Notes: -100=Severe hypotonia; -50=Mild hypotonia; 0=Normal tone; 50=Mild stiffness; 100=Severe stiffness

ElementDescription: Overall muscle tone comments
Dystonia - Distribution
Notes: 0=Absent; 33.333=Focal, one joint or posture of the body; 66.666=Segmental, affecting 2 or more joints in a segment; 100=Generalized, affecting most or all of the body

ElementDescription: Dystonia - Duration
Notes: 0=Absent; 33.333=Intermittent, less than half of exam; 66.666=Common, half or more than half of exam; 100=Persistent, all of the exam

ElementDescription: Chorea - Distribution
Notes: 0=Absent; 33.333=Upper limbs; 66.666=Upper limbs and trunk; 100=Generalized

ElementDescription: Chorea - Duration
Notes: 0=Absent; 33.333=Intermittent, less than half of exam; 66.666=Common, half or more than half of exam; 100=Persistent, all of the exam

ElementDescription: Orofacial Dyskinesia - Duration
Notes: 0=Absent; 25=Rare; 50=Intermittent, less than half of the exam; 75=Half or more of the exam; 100=All, nearly all of the exam

ElementDescription: Hand Stereotypies - Repetitive meaningless movements in the hands
Notes: 0=Absent; 25=Rare; 50=Less than half of the exam; 75=Half or more of the exam; 100=All, nearly all of the exam

ElementDescription: Leg Crossing - One hip slightly flexed/abducted and externally rotated and the ankle is placed on opposite thigh
Notes: 0=Absent; 25=Rare; 50=Less than half of the exam; 75=Half or more of the exam; 100=All, nearly all of the exam

ElementDescription: Bruxism - Grinding of teeth
Notes: 0=Absent; 25=Rare; 50=Less than half of the exam; 75=Half or more of the exam; 100=All, nearly all of the exam

ElementDescription: Describe hand stereotypies observed
Central and peripheral - None
Notes: 0=Unselected; 1=Selected

ElementDescription: Central and peripheral - Irregular breathing, observe/auscultate hyperventilation, breath holding or pauses
Notes: 0=Unselected; 1=Selected

ElementDescription: Central and peripheral - Irregular breathing with facial color change (pallor or cyanotic lips)
Notes: 0=Unselected; 1=Selected

ElementDescription: Central and peripheral - Abdominal distention due to air swallowing or constipation
Notes: 0=Unselected; 1=Selected

ElementDescription: Peripheral, pull off socks or gloves, leave for 5 minutes before assessment - None
Notes: 0=Unselected; 1=Selected

ElementDescription: Peripheral, pull off socks or gloves, leave for 5 minutes before assessment - Cold feet
Notes: 0=Unselected; 1=Selected

ElementDescription: Peripheral, pull off socks or gloves, leave for 5 minutes before assessment - Cold hands
Notes: 0=Unselected; 1=Selected

ElementDescription: Peripheral, pull off socks or gloves, leave for 5 minutes before assessment - Discolored hands or feet
Notes: 0=Unselected; 1=Selected

ElementDescription: Consolable
Notes: 0=Not required, content and relaxed; 25=Consoles on own to become content and relaxed; 50=Readily consolable, reassured by touching, distraction, talking; 75=Takes time to console - more than 2 minutes; 100=Unable to console

ElementDescription: Hyperactivity or disruptive behavior - Refers to when the child moves about constantly or excessive fidgeting or vocalizing, including in situations in which it is not appropriate
Notes: 0=Relaxed and settled; 25=Rare; 50=Less than half of the exam; 75=Half or more of the exam; 100=All, nearly all of the exam

ElementDescription: Select which items were difficult to observe during the exam - Vision
Notes: 0=Unselected; 1=Selected

ElementDescription: Select which items were difficult to observe during the exam - Gross motor function
Notes: 0=Unselected; 1=Selected

ElementDescription: Select which items were difficult to observe during the exam - Fine motor function
Notes: 0=Unselected; 1=Selected

ElementDescription: Select which items were difficult to observe during the exam - Communication
Notes: 0=Unselected; 1=Selected

ElementDescription: Select which items were difficult to observe during the exam - Alertness/Attention
Notes: 0=Unselected; 1=Selected

ElementDescription: Select which items were difficult to observe during the exam - Eye alignment and abnormal movements
Notes: 0=Unselected; 1=Selected

ElementDescription: Select which items were difficult to observe during the exam - Altered muscle tone
Notes: 0=Unselected; 1=Selected

ElementDescription: Select which items were difficult to observe during the exam - Dystonia
Notes: 0=Unselected; 1=Selected

ElementDescription: Select which items were difficult to observe during the exam - Dyskinesias
Notes: 0=Unselected; 1=Selected

ElementDescription: Select which items were difficult to observe during the exam - Stereotypies
Notes: 0=Unselected; 1=Selected

ElementDescription: Select which items were difficult to observe during the exam - Autonomic function
Notes: 0=Unselected; 1=Selected

ElementDescription: Select which items were difficult to observe during the exam - Behavior
Notes: 0=Unselected; 1=Selected

ElementDescription: Select which items were difficult to observe during the exam - None
Notes: 0=Unselected; 1=Selected

ElementDescription: Compared to the patient's condition 6 months ago, this patient's condition is:
Notes: 1=Much worse; 2=Somewhat worse; 3=A little bit worse; 4=About the same; 5=A little bit better; 6=Somewhat better; 7=Much better

ElementDescription: Clinican comments

How many antiseizure medications is your child currently taking to control seizures? (do not include any rescue medications, Vagal Nerve Stimulator, antiseizure medication used for sleep or ketogenic diet)
Notes: 1=None; 2=One antiseizure medication; 3=Two antiseizure medications; 4=Three antiseizure medications; 5=Four antiseizure medications; 6=Five or more antiseizure medications

ElementDescription: Is your child currently on the ketogenic diet, modified Atkins, or low glycemic diet for seizure control?
Notes: 0=No; 1=Yes

ElementDescription: Is your child currently using the VNS (Vagus Nerve Stimulator) for seizure control? This is a device sometimes used to treat epilepsy, implanted in the chest.
Notes: 0=No; 1=Yes

ElementDescription: How often does your child go to - Physical Therapy
Notes: 0=Never; 1=Less than 4 times per month; 2=4 times per month (weekly); 3=5-8 times per month (up to twice weekly); 4=9 or more times per month (up to three or more times per week)

ElementDescription: How often does your child go to - Speech Therapy
Notes: 0=Never; 1=Less than 4 times per month; 2=4 times per month (weekly); 3=5-8 times per month (up to twice weekly); 4=9 or more times per month (up to three or more times per week)

ElementDescription: How often does your child go to - Augmentative Communication Therapy (Please report even if it was administered as part of Speech Therapy)  ACT is a therapy that uses other devices to help non-verbal children communicate.  (Examples: iPads, Tobii, switches, picture boards)
Notes: 0=Never; 1=Less than 4 times per month; 2=4 times per month (weekly); 3=5-8 times per month (up to twice weekly); 4=9 or more times per month (up to three or more times per week)

ElementDescription: How often does your child go to - Vision Therapy
Notes: 0=Never; 1=Less than 4 times per month; 2=4 times per month (weekly); 3=5-8 times per month (up to twice weekly); 4=9 or more times per month (up to three or more times per week)

ElementDescription: How often does your child go to - Occupational Therapy
Notes: 0=Never; 1=Less than 4 times per month; 2=4 times per month (weekly); 3=5-8 times per month (up to twice weekly); 4=9 or more times per month (up to three or more times per week)

ElementDescription: How often does your child go to - Feeding Therapy
Notes: 0=Never; 1=Less than 4 times per month; 2=4 times per month (weekly); 3=5-8 times per month (up to twice weekly); 4=9 or more times per month (up to three or more times per week)

ElementDescription: How often does your child go to - Music Therapy
Notes: 0=Never; 1=Less than 4 times per month; 2=4 times per month (weekly); 3=5-8 times per month (up to twice weekly); 4=9 or more times per month (up to three or more times per week)

ElementDescription: How often does your child go to - Massage Therapy
Notes: 0=Never; 1=Less than 4 times per month; 2=4 times per month (weekly); 3=5-8 times per month (up to twice weekly); 4=9 or more times per month (up to three or more times per week)

ElementDescription: How often does your child go to - Other Therapy 1
Notes: 0=Never; 1=Less than 4 times per month; 2=4 times per month (weekly); 3=5-8 times per month (up to twice weekly); 4=9 or more times per month (up to three or more times per week)

ElementDescription: How often does your child go to - Other Therapy 2
Notes: 0=Never; 1=Less than 4 times per month; 2=4 times per month (weekly); 3=5-8 times per month (up to twice weekly); 4=9 or more times per month (up to three or more times per week)

ElementDescription: How often does your child go to - Other Therapy 3
Notes: 0=Never; 1=Less than 4 times per month; 2=4 times per month (weekly); 3=5-8 times per month (up to twice weekly); 4=9 or more times per month (up to three or more times per week)

ElementDescription: How often does your child go to - Other Therapy 1, specify
How often does your child go to - Other Therapy 2, specify
How often does your child go to - Other Therapy 3, specify
Thinking about the past 30 days, how helpful would you say have your child's therapies been altogether?
Notes: 1=Very helpful, my child is definitely gaining skills; 2=Quite helpful, my child is maintaining all skills and might be gaining slowly some skills; 3=Somewhat helpful, my child is maintaining all skills; 4=Minimally helpful, my child is mostly maintaining skills but might be losing some skills; 5=Not at all helpful, my child is definitely losing skills despite receiving therapies

ElementDescription: Has your child ever had a seizure in their life?
Notes: 0=No; 1=Yes

ElementDescription: In the past 30 days, what has been your child's longest seizure-free period? This includes ALL seizure types
Notes: 0=My child has not had any seizures in the past 30 days; 25=Seizure free for greater than 2 weeks, but less than 30 days; 50=Seizure free for greater than 1 week, but less than 2 weeks; 75=Seizure free for greater than 1 day, but less than 1 week; 100=Has had seizures every day for the past 30 days

ElementDescription: In the past 30 days, how often have your child's seizures become disruptive to his/her normal routine? This includes ALL seizure types
Notes: 0=No days in the last 30 days; 20=Only a few days in the last 30 days; 40=Fewer than half of the days in the last 30 days; 60=More than half of the days in the last 30 days; 80=Nearly every day in the last 30 days; 100=Every day in the last 30 days

ElementDescription: Convulsive Seizures
Notes: 0=No days in the last 30 days; 20=Only a few days in the last 30 days; 40=Fewer than half of the days in the last 30 days; 60=More than half of the days in the last 30 days; 80=Nearly every day in the last 30 days; 100=Every day in the last 30 days

ElementDescription: Non-Convulsive Seizures
Notes: 0=No days in the last 30 days; 20=Only a few days in the last 30 days; 40=Fewer than half of the days in the last 30 days; 60=More than half of the days in the last 30 days; 80=Nearly every day in the last 30 days; 100=Every day in the last 30 days

ElementDescription: Isolated Epileptic Spasm or Myoclonic Jerk or Single Drop
Notes: 0=No days in the last 30 days; 20=Only a few days in the last 30 days; 40=Fewer than half of the days in the last 30 days; 60=More than half of the days in the last 30 days; 80=Nearly every day in the last 30 days; 100=Every day in the last 30 days

ElementDescription: Prolonged Seizures
Notes: 0=No days in the last 30 days; 20=Only a few days in the last 30 days; 40=Fewer than half of the days in the last 30 days; 60=More than half of the days in the last 30 days; 80=Nearly every day in the last 30 days; 100=Every day in the last 30 days

ElementDescription: On average over the last 30 days, how many good days did your child have? A good day may be defined as a day that is minimally disrupted by seizures or a day where your child is engaged, interactive, and able to fully participate in activities of daily living, such as finishing therapies throughout the day
Notes: 0=Every day has been good in the last 30 days; 20=Nearly every day in the last 30 days has been good; 40=More than half of the days in the last 30 days have been good; 60=Less than half of the days in the last 30 days have been good; 80=Only a few days in the last 30 days have been good; 100=No days in the last 30 days have been good

ElementDescription: How alert has your child been over the last 30 days?
Notes: 0=My child has been very alert; 33.333=My child is alert most of the time; 66.666=My child is alert some of the time; 100=My child is rarely alert

ElementDescription: How interactive with family members or care providers has your child been over the last 30 days?
Notes: 0=My child has been very interactive; 25=My child is interactive most of the time; 50=My child is interactive some of the time; 75=My child is rarely interactive; 100=My child is never interactive

ElementDescription: How often did your child have spells of irritability, regardless of cause, in the last 30 days?
Notes: 0=No days in the last 30 days; 20=Only a few days in the last 30 days; 40=Fewer than half of the days in the last 30 days; 60=More than half of the days in the last 30 days; 80=Nearly every day in the last 30 days; 100=Every day in the last 30 days; -99=N/A - My child has never been irritable

ElementDescription: How easy or difficult was it, in general, to console your child during those spells of irritability?
Notes: 0=Very easy, my child calms down on his/her own; 25=Slightly easy, my child is pretty easy to calm down; 50=Moderately, sometimes things help, sometimes they don't; 75=Slightly difficult, it can be pretty hard to calm my child down; 100=Very difficult, inconsolable and nothing I do seems to help

ElementDescription: How often has your child self-harmed him/herself, regardless of intent or purpose, in the last 30 days?
Notes: 0=No days in the last 30 days; 20=Only a few days in the last 30 days; 40=Fewer than half of the days in the last 30 days; 60=More than half of the days in the last 30 days; 80=Nearly every day in the last 30 days; 100=Every day in the last 30 days; -99=N/A - My child has never harmed him/herself

ElementDescription: How often has your child been aggressive, regardless of intent or purpose, in the last 30 days?
Notes: 0=No days in the last 30 days; 20=Only a few days in the last 30 days; 40=Fewer than half of the days in the last 30 days; 60=More than half of the days in the last 30 days; 80=Nearly every day in the last 30 days; 100=Every day in the last 30 days; -99=N/A - My child has never been aggressive

ElementDescription: How often did your child grind their teeth during the day in the last 30 days?
Notes: 0=No days in the last 30 days; 20=Only a few days in the last 30 days; 40=Fewer than half of the days in the last 30 days; 60=More than half of the days in the last 30 days; 80=Nearly every day in the last 30 days; 100=Every day in the last 30 days; -99=N/A - My child has never grinded their teeth, or their teeth have not yet developed

ElementDescription: How well has your child made eye contact with you in the last 30 days?
Notes: 0=Direct eye contact, for total duration of an interaction; 25=He/she makes direct or indirect eye contact, holds it for at least 10 seconds, but not the total duration of an interaction; 50=He/she makes eye contact but is usually less than 10 seconds; 75=He/she makes eye contact but out the corner of his/her eye; 100=He/she doesn't really seem to look at me

ElementDescription: How well do you think your child has been able to see over the last 30 days (use your best judgement)?
Notes: 0=My child has been able to see everything in their environment; 25=My child has sometimes struggled to see objects that are small, far away, or when there is poor contrast; 50=My child can only see bright colors with contrasting background colors well; 75=My child sees lights well, but not other objects; 100=My child sees very little.

ElementDescription: Has your child had issues with reflux in the last 30 days?
Notes: 0=No; 25=Yes, but symptoms are controlled, no medications (just diet, etc.); 50=Yes, but symptoms are controlled, on medications as needed; 75=Yes, but symptoms are controlled, on daily medications; 100=Yes, despite treatments this remains a frequent struggle; -99=Unknown

ElementDescription: What best describes your child's status in terms of constipation in the last 30 days?
Notes: 0=My child has no issues with constipation; 25=My child's constipation is controlled with no medications (just diet, etc.); 50=My child's constipation is well controlled through daily medications; 75=My child's constipation is not well controlled and they take medications as needed; 100=My child's constipation remains a frequent struggle

ElementDescription: What texture of food was your child able to eat in the last 30 days?
Notes: 0=My child can eat and chew foods of any texture; 20=Foods have to be coarsely chopped; 40=Foods have to be finely chopped; 60=Foods have to be pureed or mashed; 80=My child only gets small tastes of food for pleasure; 100=My child does not take any food by mouth

ElementDescription: Which answer most accurately describes your child's G-tube/GJ-tube status?
Notes: 0=My child does not have a G-Tube/GJ-Tube; 20=My child has a G-Tube/GJ-Tube but does not routinely use it for nutrition (used for meds or as a backup); 40=My child gets their nutrition both through the G-Tube/GJ-Tube and eating by mouth; 60=All or most of my child's nutrition are provided through their G-Tube; 80=All or most of my child's nutrition are provided through their GJ-Tube; 100=My child receives nutrition through intravenous (IV) feeding (my child does not receive nutrition through their gut)

ElementDescription: How well was your child able to swallow in the last 30 days?
Notes: 0=Oral feeding with normal swallowing, no choking/gagging; 25=Oral feeding with occasional choking/gagging; 50=Oral feeding but it takes more than 30 minutes to eat meal or occasional choking/gagging possible; 75=Oral feeding with frequent choking/gagging; 100=Unable to safely swallow

ElementDescription: Did your child have signs of abnormal breathing while awake, such as breath-holding, deep breathing or rapid breathing, that was not associated with seizures in the last 30 days?
Notes: 0=No; 25=Yes, occasionally; 50=Yes, daily; 75=Yes, daily and occasional cyanosis (blueness around mouth or face); 100=Yes, daily and frequent cyanosis (blueness around mouth or face)

ElementDescription: Which best describes your child's toileting habits in the last 30 days?
Notes: 0=My child is fully toilet trained; 25=My child is toilet trained during the day but still wears diapers during the night; 50=My child is toilet training and still wears diapers at all times but mostly uses the toilet; 75=My child is toilet training and still wears diapers at all times but rarely uses the toilet; 100=My child uses diapers only

ElementDescription: Did your child have a reduced response to pain in last 30 days?
Notes: 0=No, my child had a normal response to pain; 33.333=Yes, my child had a delayed response to minor pain; 66.666=Yes, my child had no response to minor pain or a delayed response to major pain; 100=Yes, my child had neither a response to minor pain nor a response to major pain

ElementDescription: In your opinion, how often has your child had a hard time falling asleep at night in the last 30 days?
Notes: 0=No days in the last 30 days; 20=Only a few days in the last 30 days; 40=Fewer than half of the days in the last 30 days; 60=More than half of the days in the last 30 days; 80=Nearly every day in the last 30 days; 100=Every day in the last 30 days; -99=N/A - My child hasn't had a hard time falling asleep at night

ElementDescription: How often did your child wake up in the night after falling asleep in last 30 days? (Note: All children wake up during the night. Please count only those times when your child cried or was disruptive enough to need your attention)
Notes: 0=No days in the last 30 days; 20=Only a few days in the last 30 days; 40=Fewer than half of the days in the last 30 days; 60=More than half of the days in the last 30 days; 80=Nearly every day in the last 30 days; 100=Every day in the last 30 days; -99=N/A - My child has never woken up in the night after falling asleep

ElementDescription: When your child woke up during the night in the last 30 days, how long did it usually take to calm your child after they woke up and needed your attention?
Notes: 0=Less than 10 minutes, my child usually went right back to sleep; 25=10-30 minutes; 50=31-60 minutes; 75=About 1-2 hours; 100=More than 2 hours

ElementDescription: How often was your child awake during the night after falling asleep but did not need your attention in last 30 days? (Only count those times when your child was awake but not disruptive)
Notes: 0=No days in the last 30 days; 20=Only a few days in the last 30 days; 40=Fewer than half of the days in the last 30 days; 60=More than half of the days in the last 30 days; 80=Nearly every day in the last 30 days; 100=Every day in the last 30 days; -99=NA - child not monitored after I go to sleep

ElementDescription: How often was your child so sleepy during the daytime that it was disruptive to their normal routine in the last 30 days?
Notes: 0=No days in the last 30 days; 20=Only a few days in the last 30 days; 40=Fewer than half of the days in the last 30 days; 60=More than half of the days in the last 30 days; 80=Nearly every day in the last 30 days; 100=Every day in the last 30 days; -99=N/A - my child is never so sleepy during the day that it is disruptive

ElementDescription: Has your child had a serious bacterial infection requiring treatment or medicine, such as pneumonia or urinary tract infection in the last 30 days?
Notes: 0=No; 1=Yes

ElementDescription: Which type of care did this infection require? If there was more than one infection in the last 30 days, please answer for the most severe infection. Please check all that apply - Called my Primary Care Physician (PCP)
Notes: 0=Called my Primary Care Physician (PCP); 25=Visited my Primary Care Physician (PCP) or Urgent Care (UC); 50=Went to the Emergency Department (ED); 75=My child was admitted to the hospital; 100=My child needed a stay in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU)

ElementDescription: Which type of care did this infection require? If there was more than one infection in the last 30 days, please answer for the most severe infection. Please check all that apply - Visited my Primary Care Physician (PCP) or Urgent Care (UC)
Notes: 0=Unselected; 1=Selected

ElementDescription: Which type of care did this infection require? If there was more than one infection in the last 30 days, please answer for the most severe infection. Please check all that apply - Went to the Emergency Department (ED)
Notes: 0=Unselected; 1=Selected

ElementDescription: Which type of care did this infection require? If there was more than one infection in the last 30 days, please answer for the most severe infection. Please check all that apply - My child was admitted to the hospital
Notes: 0=Unselected; 1=Selected

ElementDescription: Which type of care did this infection require? If there was more than one infection in the last 30 days, please answer for the most severe infection. Please check all that apply - My child needed a stay in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU)
Notes: 0=Unselected; 1=Selected
